Accidental Release Prevention Policy:
Protecting and responsibly managing natural resources demonstrates stewardship and is critical to the quality of life in the communities we serve, to the environment, and to Davis Gas Processing, Inc.'s (DGP's) long-term business success.  Promoting the health and safety of co-workers, contractors, customers, and communities is the responsibility of all DGP employees.  DGP will comply with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations.
 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
Denton Gas Plant (Denton), located near Lovington, Lea County, New Mexico, is a natural gas liquids processing plant that produces pipeline specification residue gas and natural gas liquids from field gas collected throughout the gathering system.  Denton handles flammable gas and liquid mixtures in an amount greater than the threshold quantity containing one of more of the following RMP-regulated constituents:
¿	Methane
¿	Ethane
¿	Propane
¿	Isobutane
¿	Butane
¿	Isopentane
¿	Pentane
 
The only RMP-regulated toxic constituent present at Denton, which is part of the inlet gas and amine treating process, is hydrogen sulfide; however, quantities at Denton are well below the threshold quantity. 
 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
DGP is committed to ensuring a safe work environment for all its employees, contractors, and vendors.  The Denton Gas Plant has a detailed Emergency Action Plan in which it has coordinated with the community's local responders in an effort to introduce them to the facility and its personnel.
 
General Accidental Release Prevention Program:
The Denton process is covered by OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM) regulation.  DGP considers the systems developed for compliance with PSM to be the basis for good safety and business practices.  In this effort, DGP identifies opportunities to continuously improve initiatives for each PSM ele

ment.  The PSM elements are implemented to satisfy the PSM requirements and are discussed here for completeness only since the Denton Gas Plant qualifies as a program level 1 RMP process.
 
Employee Participation:
Employee participation is the foundation block to an evergreen and integrated PSM program.  Thus, the current PSM improvement initiative is heavily focused on this key element as employees are becoming more actively involved in the implementation of each element of PSM.
 
Process Safety Information:
Comprehensive reviews of the available process safety information (PSI) have been conducted.  Updates to the maximum intended inventory (MII).  New piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) and area classification drawings are under development along with material balances for completion in late 2019/early 2020.  A comprehensive electronic web-based system utilized for timely access to information has been built, implemented, and made available to all personnel involved with process operations.  
 
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):
A new PHA procedure has been established for DGP.  A new comprehensive PHA team including a highly experienced third-party PHA facilitator, experienced DGP operating personnel (operations and maintenance), DGP engineers, Process Control personnel, safety representatives, and PSM representatives will be utilized to conduct a new PHA in the latter part of 2019.  The previous PHA was performed at Denton on November 16, 2016.  Results and recommendations from these analyses will be shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PHA action items to closure.
 
Operating Procedures:
A gap analysis and completion of all discovered gaps in Denton operating procedures is in process.  Operating procedures will be updated to reflect current operations and identified gaps in operating procedures (such as various modes of process operations) will be

developed.  After the operating procedures are completed, they will be published to the company's electronic web-based system and used in the operations training program.  
 
Management of Change (MOC) and Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):
Improvements to the MOC procedure and associated checklists are in progress to capture all process related changes.  Requirements for the identification, evaluation, control, and authorization of modifications to plant design and operations prior to the implementation to ensure that the risk of new or existing hazards are properly managed is available to all personnel.  Extensive PSSR checklists for applicable disciplines (electrical, instrumentation, procedures, etc.) have been developed and implemented.  These checklists are Appendices to the Company's MOC procedure and are available online from the company's electronic web-based process library. 
 
Mechanical Integrity (MI):
In addition to the ultrasonic thickness testing program already in practice at Denton, a complete third-party MI gap assessment has been completed.  A third-party contractor is developing global DGP MI procedures.  After completion of these procedures, any identified MI gaps will be addressed to ensure the development of comprehensive inspection standards and procedures along with a specialized inspection program structured specifically for Denton.  The MI schedule for all DGP facilities is currently in development.  The Denton MI should be completed by the end of 2020.
 
Incident Investigation:
DGP investigates all PSM incidents.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, incident investigation procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.  A mix of DGP personnel will be provided investigation methodology training to further enhance the program and ensure root cause is consistently identified.  A process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented to track action items and incident investigation corrective actio

ns to closure.  Third-party contractors will coordinate the investigation of any high-risk incidents. 
 
Compliance Audits:
To meet compliance with PSM, DGP conducts compliance audits every three years to verify all PSM element requirements are being satisfied.  In DGP's general PSM improvement program initiatives, an updated audit protocol has been established and implemented within DGP.  A new team including experienced PSM representatives, DGP engineers, operating personnel (operations and maintenance), and safety representatives will be utilized to conduct new PSM Compliance Audit.  The last audit conducted at Denton was on November 16 and November 17, 2016.  Results and action items from all audits will be shared with employees.  Additionally, a process safety tracking tool has been developed and implemented for the interactive tracking of PSM compliance action items to closure.
  
Hot Work Permit:
Hot work permits are in use and on file.  These permits are uploaded onto the company's electronic web-based process library.  Throughout the PSM program assessment process, all hot work procedures are being reviewed and will be updated as necessary.
 
Contractors:
DGP has an electronic program for contractors that includes their safety records.  A review of the contractor's safety records both prior to selection and during their time of employment is in progress.  Written contractor and visitor safety orientation training materials have been developed and implemented at Denton.  DGP is in process of developing a safety training video that all contractors and visitors must see before gaining access to the Denton Gas Plant.
 
Training:
With the enhancement of various PSM elements such as PSI, PHAs, operating procedures, PSSR, MI, MOC, incident investigations, etc., additional training (computer and classroom based) will be established to ensure all Denton employees are knowledgeable in these processes.
 
Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
The process a

t Denton has hazards that must be managed for continued safe operation.  Following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.
 
Universal Prevention Activities
The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the RMP-covered process at Denton.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.
 
Specialized Safety Features:
 
The Denton Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help:
I.	contain/control a release
II.	quickly detect a release
III.	reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release

Release Detection
I.	Hydrogen sulfide detectors with alarms located in designated process areas
II.	Routine operator rounds/equipment inspections
III.	Operators are on-site continually (8,760 hours per year)
 
Release containment/control measures include:
I.	Main process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases
II.	Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process
III.	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)
IV.	Curbing to contain liquid releases
V.	Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system).
VI.	Atmospheric relief devices
 
Release mitigation measures include:
I.	Fire extinguishing systems
II.	Personnel trained in the site's emergency response plan
III.	Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
 
Emergency Response Program:
The overall emergency response program for Denton has been coordinated with several local emergency responders that include the Lea County Sheriff's Department, Lovington Police Department, Lovington Fire Department, and local medical providers in Lea County.  The Denton Gas Plant has around-th

e-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department, Police and Sheriff's office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Denton may implement mock emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations and will conduct additional emergency drills annually with local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.
 
Five-Year Accident History:
A review of all incidents that occurred at the Denton Gas Plant during the previous five years was conducted to determine whether incidents were subject to the RMP accident history reporting requirements specified in 40 CFR 68.195(a).  There have been no accidental releases of regulated substances meeting the accident reporting criteria of 40 CFR 68.42(a) during the prior five years or any that preclude meeting the program level 1 requirements of 40 CFR 68.10(b)(1).
 
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
DGP Denton will continue to improve its safety and environmental performance through emphasis on the continued development of its PSM Program.  Improvement plans include continued process engineering support to update critical PSI data for the site; updating operating procedures written for each mode of operation and to include consequences of deviations; an operator certification training program established from the new operating procedures, new process hazard analysis (PHA) procedure and team structure ensuring employee involvement, new MI program incorporating the implementation of all new inspection procedures and frequencies all to be carefully reviewed, and recommendations for improvement generated using DGP's new compliance audit process.
